awd_titl_txt: CRII: III: Generative Models for Robust Real-Time Analysis of Complex Dynamic Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Many complex systems in the computer, information, biological, and social sciences can be represented as networks with nodes denoting objects and edges denoting relationships between the objects. Such complex network structures often change continuously over time through the observation of events at irregular times, such as networks of social interactions between people via messages, networks of transactions between organizations, and networks of face-to-face interactions between people. This project formulates a range of models of varying complexity for continuously evolving networks to enable robust real-time analysis of these networks in a variety of application settings. Such dynamic network models could be used in many scientific disciplines and in public health applications, including modeling the spread of airborne viruses between people. The project trains new graduate and undergraduate students, including female students from the University of Toledo's ACM-W chapter, in practical data science research involving a variety of data types and sources. The project also results in the development of an open-source Python software package, DyNetworkX, for analyzing dynamic networks along with educational materials on dynamic networks through a series of lectures and hands-on tutorials using the DyNetworkX package.

This project aims to create a range of probabilistic generative models for continuous-time event-based networks that are flexible enough to account for the types of complex structures seen in real network data, including node popularity, community structure, reciprocity, and transitivity. The project also seeks to develop efficient incremental inference algorithms and discrete-time approximations that allow for real-time analysis of extremely large social networks that are rapidly changing over time, such as those seen in online social network data. The proposed range of models allows an analyst to trade off flexibility and scalability depending on the needs of a particular application. Two main applications are targeted: prediction of the spread of infectious disease over networks of physical proximity and real-time summarization and prediction of online social network activity. Deliverable assets of the project include new probabilistic models and inference algorithms, the DyNetworkX open-source software package, and educational materials on dynamic networks. These are intended to benefit researchers and educators in the computer and information sciences as well as researchers in other fields such as the social and economic sciences, software engineers, and hobbyists who work with dynamic network data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Many complex systems in the computer, information, biological, and social sciences can be represented as networks, with nodes denoting objects and edges denoting relationships between the objects. The behaviors of such complex systems, and hence their network structures, often change continuously over time.

The main objective of this project was to create a range of probabilistic generative models for continuously evolving networks that provide plausible mechanisms by which the network data are generated in order to reveal insights about the underlying complex system. Different proposed models in the range varied in complexity, which allows an analyst to trade off flexibility and scalability of the model depending on the application setting. The focus of the project was on two applications on opposite ends of the range: modeling the spread of infectious disease over face-to-face interaction networks, which required highly flexible models, and modeling communication patterns on online social networks, which required highly scalable models for very large networks.

The main research contribution was the development of 4 probabilistic generative models of varying scalability and flexibility. On one end of the tradeoff is the community Hawkes independent pairs (CHIP) model that scales up to millions of nodes, and on the other end is the latent space Hawkes (LSH) model that scales only to thousands of nodes but can replicate a much larger variety of structures observed in real network data. The proposed models were demonstrated to be more accurate than existing models in two tasks: predicting future network structure (predictive accuracy) and replicating features from the network (generative accuracy). They were evaluated on a variety of real network data sets, including email networks, online social networks, and militarized disputes between countries.

The research findings from this project have been presented at and published in the proceedings of multiple international conferences. They have also lead to the completion of 2 PhD dissertations, 2 MS theses, and 1 BS Honors thesis, with several others in progress.

A broader impact of this project was the development of the open-source DyNetworkX Python software package for analyzing dynamic network data (available at the URL https://github.com/IdeasLabUT/dynetworkx). The development team has also created documentation for the DyNetworkX package and several analysis examples in the form of Jupyter notebooks. This package can benefit not only researchers and educators in the computer and information sciences, but also researchers in other fields such as the social and economic sciences, software engineers, and hobbyists who work with dynamic network data.

Several of the investigators on this project have also given tutorials on modeling and analysis of dynamic network data at major international conferences. These tutorials include examples using the CHIP model and DyNetworkX package, both developed as part of this project.

Finally, this project has also supported the University of Toledo's ACM-W (women in computing) chapter, which PI Xu co-founded and served as faculty mentor. Members of the UToledo ACM-W chapter has participated in and won prizes in several hackathons, including the grand prize as SDHacks 2018.


Last Modified: 04/30/2022
Modified by: Kevin S Xu
